intro: Dyschoriste quitensis, commonly known as the Andean chervil, is a flowering plant native to the Andes region of South America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, greenish-yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in high-altitude environments, often in rocky or arid soils, and is adapted to the cool, temperate climate of its native habitat. Dyschoriste quitensis is also noted for its aromatic leaves, which are sometimes used in traditional Andean cuisine. Its botanical features make it an important component of the local flora and ecosystem in the Andean region.
